awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Modeling Assessment to Enhance Teaching and Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
Although many in education advocate for evidence-based teaching, implementation of such practices is often quite difficult for teachers. Assessment and accountability data are commonly used for system-level reforms, but are seldom designed to help teachers guide day-to-day instructional decision-making. More useful assessment systems should deliver actionable information to assist in guiding instructional decisions, communicate the development of student knowledge, and integrate various forms of data to assist teachers. Such systems must be logistically feasible to implement, provide suitable grounds for interpreting  information about achievement, and exist in a teacher community interested in ongoing feedback about student learning.

This project will modify an existing assessment system (BEAR Assessment System) to provide ongoing, instructionally productive evidence to teachers about student learning and to link student work products and formative assessments with summative assessments in models that generate useful estimates of student growth. To design and test the assessment system, researchers will study teacher integration of assessment tools with instruction via classroom observations, video records, and interviews. Feedback from teachers and observations of their assessment practices will inform revisions to the assessment system. Multiple iterations will focus on how best to represent and display assessment results for tracking individual and group learning. Researchers will investigate new psychometric models that link information from student classroom work, responses to formative assessments, and summative evaluations to provide more reliable estimates of student learning.

The Discovery Research PreK-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools (RMTs). Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

por.por_cntn:
Although the purposes of assessment are varied, there is widespread agreement about the need to account for the extent to which educational systems advance student learning. Yet, the forms and formats of assessments often ill serve students and teachers, partly because summative judgments of student performance frequently fail to capture student performance in ways that are specific and actionable for teachers. For example, measures of student proficiency in solving mathematics problems often fail to articulate the strategies and concepts that students are employing. Timing is another key barrier to the utility of summative assessment. Summative evaluations that occur only at the end of the school year may serve future students, but do not help teachers better support the students who were tested. In turn, although formative assessments are designed to provide actionable grounds to improve the quality of instruction on the basis of both the granularity and specificity of their content and their timing, unfortunately, their psychometric qualities are often unexamined and hence must be interpreted cautiously.

 To address these problems, this project produced an assessment system that continuously generated actionable information for improving classroom instruction in mathematics in the elementary grades (K-5). The system employs innovative psychometric models developed by our partners at Berkeley that integrate student responses to summative assessments with ongoing classroom embedded observations of student learning by teachers. Teacher observations included in-the-moment snapshots of student strategies and products during instruction as well as student responses to formative assessments.

 The assessment system was developed in partnership with teachers to generate (1) a shared conceptual frame for describing instructional goals and valued forms of teaching and learning; (2) a set of electronic tools to help teachers detect, share, analyze, and interpret student data; (3) classroom and school-level community professional development structures to support and sustain a widespread practice of assessing student learning to guide instruction; and (4) an item bank designed for interim formative and end-of-year summative measure of student learning. A shared conception of valued forms of student learning was generated by articulating conceptual waypoints, or constructs, in student understandings of the mathematics of measure (of length, angle, area, volume) and of associated understandings of rational number (as quantities and as operators on quantities). Formative and summative items indexed student learning of particular waypoints of one or more constructs, as did teacher observations and records of students’ classroom learning activity. Digital tools produced by the project facilitated teacher records of student learning and allowed both individual teachers and communities of teachers to track and share evidence of student progress. Professional development meetings included monthly participation in collective investigation and interpretation of student thinking within classrooms and summer institutes in which teachers charted the course of future instruction and investigated the mathematics of measure. Teachers also contributed to continual improvement of researcher-designed curriculum units to support student learning. 

The project also developed and implemented measures of teacher learning. These measures indicated that there were substantial transitions in what teachers noticed about student learning, in their development of practices tuned to assisting student learning of key concepts of measure, and in their generation of evidence of student learning associated with benchmarks of the learning constructs.

Because teachers came to interpret learning in terms of a shared set of constructs, it was feasible to integrate teachers’ judgments of student learning with those estimated by summative assessments. This integration was accomplished by item response modeling that viewed teacher judgments as random items indicating a student’s location at particular waypoints of a construct. These classroom-based estimates in turn, were combined with estimates of performance levels indicated by student responses to summative assessments, resulting in greater reliability of estimates of learning. These complemented the actionable information for improving student learning that was generated during the course of instruction, so that the assessment system could inform decision-making at multiple levels of scale (e,g. classroom, school, district) and of time (e.g. immediate, quarterly, yearly).
